abstracts.cdata!:
Despite a satisfactory project outcome,
            sustainability is unlikely, while institutional development
            impacts were only modest. These ratings are reflected
            through the lessons learned, as follows. Nepal's image
            has suffered tremendously due to the political instability,
            and ensuing polarization between the key political actors.
            This image has clearly worsened the investment climate,
            particularly foreign investment, and has dampened growth
            prospects. An alleged escalation of human rights abuses, by
            both sides of the military conflict is also a prime concern
            for development partners, who feel strongly that the current
            political/military situation in Nepal is not conducive to
            Bank support. Notwithstanding, the dialogue between the Bank
            and the borrower needs to be maintained at all levels during
            this uncertain period. The Bank can play a constructive role
            by continuing to support the reform-minded technocrats who
            spearheaded the Poverty Reduction strategy Paper (PRSP). The
            costs of not remaining engaged would likely be serious as it
            would leave reformers isolated, while the momentum for
            certain reforms would be lost. The distinction between
            technocrat and politician-driven reforms is important. There
            remain many important reforms that are relatively
            non-controversial (e.g. reducing transit costs and improving
            connectivity) and can be spearheaded by committed
            technocrats. At the same time, there are other reforms that
            can have a clear short run political cost such as adjusting
            petroleum prices. Related to this is the fact that if
            technocrat-driven reforms are to be sustained, there has to
            be a concerted effort to limit transfers in key
            secretary-level positions. Further addressed are lessons on
            the trade-off between the predictability of budget support
            and the strength of the annual reform program; on the
            ability to communicate the rationale behind reforms; that
            reforms in the judiciary system clearly lag behind reforms
            on other fronts; and, that major policy shifts in service
            delivery require a detailed implementation plan.
